description.narrative:
Det övergripande målet med projektet är att öka synliggörandet av kvinnor och bekämpa könsstereotyper i det politiska deltagandet på nationell och lokal nivå i Ukraina. Projektet bygger på ett redan existerande projekt som startades i oktober 2013 (Promoting women as political leaders, Plus- id 55070049) och tar tillvara på relevanta erfarenheter ur detta projekt. Fokus ligger på tre övergripande områden: 1) Att främja medvetenhet om fördelarna med jämlikhet mellan könen och att bekämpa negativa stereotyper kring kvinnor 2) Att öka synliggörandet av kvinnliga politiska ledare 3) Att bilda koalitioner mellan kvinnliga ledare på nationell och lokal nivå
Aktiviteter kommer att inkludera, dock ej enbart: - Fortsatta utbildningar för journalister kring könsstereotyper i media - Fortsatt stöd till websidan Povaha som syftar till att öka medvetenheten kring könsstereotyper - TEDx Talks i Ukraina - Offentliga informationskampanjer för kvinnors deltagande i politiken - Att stödja samarbete och nätverkande mellan aktiva kvinnliga politiker
The overarching goal of the project is to increase visibility of women and combat gender stereotype in the national and local politics of Ukraine.

The results framework is clearly presented with an overall programme goal which is: "In partnership with Ukrainian NGOs, build awareness of the importance of increasing women´s political leadership". More concretely the objectives are the following: ? to promote awareness among opinion makers of the benefits of gender equality and combating negative stereotyping of women; ? to raise the visibility of women leaders ? to facilitate the formation of coalitions among women leaders at the national and local levels.
The activity period of the project was 2015.04.01 - 2017.03.31 and Sida's total budget amounted to SEK 11 548 425.

Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: The reporting is quite activity based and it is evident that NDI and its partners have been very active and that much has been done through the course of the project. Along with its cooepration partners, NDI organized national and regional public events such as inter-regional forums, media marathons, public seminars, and training sessions for media officials. NDI continued to work with the Povaha and 50 Percent websites which address discrimination and promote women's political participation. Over the project period both websites grew quickly and conversations about gender equality and sexism are becoming more coherent among gender equality advocates and topics involving gender equality are more openly discussed in the mainstream. NDI assesses that 8 million Ukrainians have been exposed to the program's messages online and through television. Regular visitors to the two websites that were created (Povaha and 50 Percent) are increasing, indicating their importance as platforms for the public to discuss gender issues Women were featured at the organized regional and national events and campaigns on the above mentioned websites in order to increase their visibility. An "Ask a Woman" database was created with female experts on several topics in order to encourage journalists to interview and profile women experts more frequently. 24 new local or oblast-level women's caucuses were formed in five oblasts and they worked across party lines on issues such as pollution control, acces to healthcare and provision of childcare. They also led government efforts to improve transparency. Their efforts in Kropyvnytskyi led for instance to the council passing a budget in 2017 that included 3 000 000 UAH in discretionary funds for city development projects. Proposals for how the funds should be llocated can be submitted by citizens online (where citizens can also vote on which proposal should be implemented). NDI continued working with the Equal Opporunities Caucus (EOC) in the parliament which now is a well-known national actor. The EOC has also strenghtened its relationship with the civil society through the creation of the Public Council on Gender, including many organizations from the civil society.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
